subject: Home & DIY
title: The Klismos Chair's Timeless Curves
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Klismos Chair's Timeless Curves usable.

hook.text: Ancient Greek potters painted a chair 2,500 years ago that still looks contemporary. Designers call it the Klismos.

buildup.text: The Klismos has four curved legs (saber legs) that splay outward and a concave backrest that hugs the spine.

discovery.text: Its design is ergonomic by accidentâ€”the curved back matches your lumbar spine better than most modern chairs.

twist.text: The design vanished for 2,000 years until neoclassical designers rediscovered it from Greek pottery illustrations.

climax.text: Robsjohn-Gibbings recreated it in the 1960s. Today it influences dining chairs by designers who never heard of it.

punchline.text: The perfect chair was designed before year zero.

quiz.question: What makes the ancient Greek Klismos chair ergonomically effective?
options: Its curved backrest matches the spine's natural shape
It uses a spring mechanism under the seat
It adjusts height with a wooden screw
